reviewText:
After (too many) years playing this game, I could sum it up like this :

Pros :
- Free to Play.
- Unique RvRvR gameplay.
- Fun fort and open field wars.
- Mostly open-world.
- Freedom of being able to do whatever you want at any time.
- Simple and straightforward.
- Nice community.
- Free of Asian-MMO nonsense.
- Light on system resources.
- Premium not directly influencing gameplay.
- Linux support.

Cons :
- Rubbish controls. (eg: not able to rebind spell keys)
- Grinding nightmare. (And you need to be fairly high-level (>45) in order to get fun from the RvR.)
- Really stale, boring and partially broken combat mechanics.
- Omnipresent luck and randomness. (Enjoy having your spells and hits randomly being resisted and evaded for no reason)
- Game of numbers with no diminishing returns system of any sort. (Usually the realm with most numbers will always stomp while outnumbered ones will be completely helpless.)
- Very dull quest system riddled with bad translations.
- Extremely basic guard and mob AI.
- No crafting or jobs.
- Very limited and crappy character customisation.
- Fundamental design flaws leading to perpetual class and map imbalance.
- Premium indirectly and increasingly impacting gameplay.
- Out of date graphics.
- Dull and repetitive sounds/music.
- Worriying direction the game is taking (such as ruining RvR by implementing instances).
- Support system sucks.
- Same map that will appear boring and small after a while.
- Not many capturable buildings.
- Many hours of boredom before a few minutes of action happen most of the days, at least in the International server.
- Not much to do in this game outside of grinding and warring.
- Developers track record not really good, and sometimes acting in very unprofessional manners.
- Major ignored problems, imbalances and bugs still ruining this game after so many years.
- Lacks a ton of polishing in many aspects.
- Linux and OpenGL support partially broken, many extra bugs and missing graphical features.

I would have recommended this game a few years ago when it still had an interesting and unique potential, however not much improvement, and instead a lot of regressions have happenned in the past few years, while the root issues haven't been cared about so far.

So as a conclusion, if you're looking for a well-made polished and complete MMO then you should not even bother with this. If you don't mind most of the aforementioned cons (especially grinding) and look for something simple, you might get some fun and new friends from it.

reviewText:
Short version: Free. MMO. Linux. Surprising quality for beta. 'Nuff said! 8/10, with room for improvement!

Long version:
Let's get the ugly bits out of the way. This game did not work when I first downloaded it (Linux). I had to reboot a couple times, use the update tool, and then suddenly - success, I got the game to launch! I'm pretty sure the default video mode was unhappy with my dual-monitor setup. This is standard fare for Linux gaming, so I was not dissuaded.

Once I had it running, I was very impressed. This game is clearly in beta; there are occasional graphical glitches and inline error codes that really don't impact gameplay at all. Looking beyond this, however, we see a highly immersive and surprisingly well-polished MMO. There are several interesting and unique features that make this game stand out, even when stacked against its more well-funded peers. The regular PvE game is nicely paced and the quests are for the most part easy to follow. From what I've seen, the classes are well-balanced and there are enough features to keep things interesting for a very long time. The postgame feature, 3-way RvR, is a really great idea and stands out in the crowd. I'm not much of a PvP guy, but this system really makes me want try it and stick with it. As it stands now, the game is great, and I love playing it - but the potential for greatness is immense.

Graphics: Beautifully done, with a unique art style that stands out. Needs a touch of polish in spots.
Sound: Solid all around. Beautiful soundtrack, appropriate effects.
Gameplay: Genre standard, well implemented and well delivered. Combat variety abounds.
Controls: Intuitive and well-designed. A couple small snags, but nothing frustrating.
Replay value: This game is HUGE and just begs you to keep coming back!

Final word: TRY IT. If you like MMO, and you can handle a few minor glitches, you'll probably love this game!

reviewText:
rather cliche and average MMORPG with plenty of grinding and simple combat. Only real interesting thing that sets it apart (not saying that this is an original idea) is the realm vs realm combat.

Pros:
Free to play, so at least you aren't wasting money if you don't like it.


Works for linux and mac

Cons:
Extremely cliche. The story and setting is absolutely boring and terrible, so don't get the game for that.

The gameplay is just a grindfest. You right click on an enemy and it exchanges blows with your character until it dies. Then you pick up the money it dropped so that you can buy weapons to kill enemies faster.
I am sad to say that the gameplay is just typical, cliche, generic fantasy mmorpg - that means stats, leveling, equipment that increases stats, quests, and a whole crapload of grinding.
I personally cannot enjoy a game where the main premise is to right click on an enemy, and then wander around until you can find an IDENTICAL enemy to right click on so that you an right click on stronger enemies.

Terrible gameplay aside, the other reason this game sucks is simply that it is BORING.
Gameplay is almost identical to other fantasy MMORPGs, and it offers absolutely nothing original except for the (cliche and uninteresting) world and setting. The gameplay offers nothing new, and it has terrible graphics.

Conclusion:
Maybe this game had some potential.
But like most games of it's type, it feels like it is simply designed to extract money from you with it's in game currency.

The graphics are terrible, the sotryline is terrible, the world and setting are increibly redundant, cliche and boring and feels like it was ripped off the face of hundreds of other fantasty MMORPGs.
The gameplay is absolutely abysmal and is incredibly boring and repetitive.

Perhaps this game's saving grace could have been it's 'free to play' status.
It may be free to play, but it is also pay to win.

Maybe you could enjoy this game if you hada few friends, and i have the utmost respect if you wish to play this game. It's free to play, so even if this review didn't convince you to immediately exit the store page, at least you didn't waste any money.

This game is your typical moneygrab buggy grindfest. It looks terrible, and it feels terrible. Frankly, it's terrible and you would be better off playing pac-man, which at least has decent gameplay.
This is my honest opinion about this game. I know this seems like a huge long hate-rant, and it probably is, but I just can't help but feel this game is a poorly-crafted attempt to squeeze a few cents out of gamers, because I honestly can't see anything worthwhile.

Hub-based ! quests and combat that requires you to stay completely still (even changing the angle of the camera or your character's facing stops your current action).  Menus are sometimes confusing to navigate and the game seems as though it was translated from another language entirely (and poorly at that).  Attention to detail is abysmally low (I read that a dummy dodged my blow and I'll reckon that structures as well might do that.)\nThe game has a stat system, but that only attempts to pidgeonhole the player into a certain race/faction in order to play a class they're interested in to its potential.  There are hints of a crafting system but I couldn't get far enough in before the game disconnected me and I just don't have the heart to launch it again.\nThe endgame PVP might be interesting, but it seems like it wouldn't be too interesting in fixed-camera combat from 10 years ago.

reviewText:
I'm sorry. I wish I could recommend this game, but I really can't.

I knew going in that this would be no ESO. I knew it would not be as good as WoW. I did not know, however, that it would be as unfinished as it is.

Firstly, the camera/movement/combat systems are super unintuitive. The fustercluck of clicking and dragging combined with the fact that Q and E also control the choppy camera rotation make it impossible to find a good rhythm for combat.

Secondly, and probably most importantly, no one is wearing any clothes. The women are all fully naked, while the men wear a glitched-out pair of invisible boxer briefs. I step into the introductory valley (called Introduction Valley, or something similar) and walk into a scene that could easily have been the result of mixing multiple nudity mods on Skyrim. Without the benefit of 2011 graphics.

I like that the game takes place in a high fantasy setting (with no excessive anime influences, which, to be honest tend to spoil the genre for me). Beyond that, the only thing I like about the game is that I didn't have to spend any money on it to realize how poorly executed it was.

So this review will not reflect based off of your skill level or experiences, but limited to ours, but in this case my own.  IN SIMPLE TERMS.....



REVIEW:  In a nutshell not a bad game, but lacked that excited-to-replay value for me compared to RIFT, WOW, Runes of Magic and many other MMORPGs currently and in the past.



I give it a POOR overall rating and below tells why

4/10   ☼☼☼☼   :-(



PROS:  A bit grey = not any one stands out as spectacular

Colorful visuals

Familiar Controls

Familiar Interface

Familiar Questing Format

Fort Battles



CONS:  A bit Black and white = small problems but very frequent or just straight bad


SMALL THINGS:

Skill synergy hesitation (from one to another timer/inerupts by delays) is awful

Ability visuals a bit drab even at highest settings

Character Customization could've been a bit better

Leveling could be a bit faster to stay competitive even though I got a max level in about 20 hours, but most I have talked to outside of my colleagues all said the same thing, excussing the occasional other pro gamer and/or a speed leveler.

Standard money trap to make the best gear which is an outdated and/or already dying idea

No professions



BIG THINGS:

Movement a bit clunky = jump and while using skills

A.I. in this game is one of the worst I have ever experienced

DEVs lack the ability to stay competitive with all other successful MMORPGs by effective updates.  I really think they think the way things are now is going to eventually work, but it will never turn around.  MAKES THIS FEEL LIKE A DEAD END GAME

PvP in idea is nice, but with above stated clunkiness and poor skill synergy makes it taxing and one-sided to certain class types  unbalanced on a HUGE scale.  When I played alot I was in top ranks all the time, but limited by class to take it more seriously.  Being forced to play classes you don't want just to succeed is ne of the worst experiences ever and kills MMOs fr me and my circles when this happens.

Getting to max level very quickly and then wishing you didn't because end-game content is over in a blink of an eye.

SKILLS were not so bad going from one to another (speed)

INCREASED/BETTER MOVEMENT while using skills

More of a Auction House centered community

Classes were balanced or at least a bit more so for PvP, squashing the one-sidedness factor for most teams and allowing a more overall variety in playstyles

My reviews are based off of whether I would recommend the game to the community as a whole.  I personally love this game, but I can't recommend it to everyone.

Basis of the Worlds:

There are three areas to choose from: Syrtis; The forested lands, Alsius; the arctic lands, and Ignis; the badlands/desert.  It is built to be a PvP (or rather Realm vs Realm) game the way it it set up; stealing artfacts and capturing towers in the name of your kingdom.
At first glance, each kingdom is well put-together.  You later realise that most of your kingddom is a barren wasteland, with nothing to do but grind enemies.

The Community:

The community on here is rather small, but it is both active and kind.

Basis of Combat:

There are three classes to choose from: Melee, Archery, and Magic, which can further be divided based on how you wish to play.  It's been a while, so I don't quite remember the class names aside from the warior's subclasses of Knight and Barbarian.     It doesn't get exceedingly difficult as far as combat mechanics go.  It's simply click, click again to attack, and pick a number for a quick technique.

The Leveling:

At first, the grind is not as apparent as you'd think.  You tend to level easily for the first ten levels or so upon simply turning in quests.  However, it becomes a monotonous slaughterfest trying to grind out enemies to reach the next level.  Quests begin to be more trouble than reward, so grinding enemies becomes the best option.

People see you are able to but items with real money, so they immediatelly critisize the game for being a pay to win" game.  This couldn't be further from the truth.  There is ONE thing that seems mandetory to buy; that is a mount.  All a mount does is allow for quicker travel IN YOUR OWN KINGDOM
